12.95.text:
Trip Jennings: I was thinking
about what to say about risk

16.42.text:
and why we take it,
preparing for this presentation,

22.05.text:
when I thought a whole lot
about that question,

26.86.text:
I was dangling
from a very thin rope,

29.03.text:
not a climbing rope
but a throw rope

30.90.text: that you use in a kayak,

34.50.text:
to the bottom of the
Pandi River Canyon

36.64.text:
in the very remote jungles
of Papua New Guinea.

39.74.text: Here's a shot of the river

40.97.text:
as it flows out of the mouth of
the Pandi River.

46.01.text:
I had had the most terrifying
experience

49.08.text: I've ever had in a river.

50.68.text:
I was 100 feet down into
the canyon...

54.45.text:
...when I reached the end
of my rope.

55.86.text:
Still 40 feet
from the very bottom.

58.09.text:
And, so, I had to wait
for like an hour

60.69.text:
while my friends
walked through the jungle

63.56.text:
to get some more rope
to lower down to me.

65.16.text:
So, that was a
pretty good moment, right,

74.04.text:
we'd come to Papua New Guinea
to paddle the source

76.01.text:
to sea descent of the
Pandi River.

77.48.text:
Right, it was a river that had
never been explored in a kayak.

80.18.text:
The reason
we'd chosen this river

87.32.text:
So we wanted to use
our adventure story

89.59.text: to tell a story about a culture

91.72.text:
and ecosystem
on a brink of change.

93.79.text:
We started at the
underground source of the Pandi,

97.83.text: And we made our way down

99.43.text:
through some
of the most beautiful

101.60.text:
and amazing white water
I've ever seen,

107.41.text: And towards the end of the day,

110.21.text: we got to a point where

112.75.text:
the whole Pandi River
poured off of a 20 foot cliff

115.55.text:
into this cauldron where all of
the water re-circulated back

119.32.text:
upstream into a cave
behind the waterfall.

123.22.text: It was way too dangerous to run,

124.52.text:
even though
it wasn't a big drop,

125.82.text:
but it was
way too dangerous to run.

127.76.text:
Because that's not
a good place to be;

131.43.text:
And so,
it was almost dark,

135.37.text:
and the canyon walls were
100 feet vertical on all sides.

140.07.text: There's no way out but down.

141.67.text:
That's the worst place you ever
want to be in a kayak, right?

146.95.text:
And so we decided
what we would do,

148.31.text:
is we would make our way
on to this small cliff

150.45.text:
as far downstream as we
could on river right.

152.99.text:
We'd hop in our kayaks
and slide off of the cliff

156.12.text:
into the river
and if we did it just right,

158.12.text:
we'd be downstream
of the upstream flow.

161.79.text:
The re-circulation area.
We'd make it out all right?

164.73.text:
So, I went forth
in the twilight, almost dark.

170.54.text:
I caught the very first eddy
that I could,

172.37.text:
so I could stop and run safety
for Matt Fields-Johnson.

175.81.text:
He was our photographer
on the expedition

178.01.text:
and the least experienced member
of the crew.

180.05.text:
And I watched him
slide off of the...

183.45.text:
the sort of cliff,
the precipice there,

186.19.text:
and watched his boat
turn sideways in the air,

189.49.text:
land, flip
and get sucked upstream

193.26.text:
behind the waterfall into,
kind of, the worst place to be.

197.56.text:
And,
he rolled a few times,

201.10.text:
lost his paddle,
flipped over again

203.30.text:
and swam out of his kayak.
His kayak went downstream

205.81.text:
and he was stuck
in this really turbulent pool,

209.54.text:
every now and then
getting a breath.

211.61.text:
And, thankfully, Brian Eustis
was still on the cliff.

216.78.text:
He tried again and again
to toss him a rope, right,

218.68.text:
to get him anything to help him
get out of that spot,

221.65.text:
and he just couldn't because
the cliff was so overhung.

225.32.text: And so, after a few minutes,

233.33.text:
totally out of breath and
totally exhausted.

235.27.text:
And I was watching
my friend Matt drown.

240.31.text:
And I couldn't do
anything about it

241.57.text:
because the current separated me
from where he was.

243.84.text:
And so, at the very,
sort of, very last resort...

251.15.text: He just tossed all of the rope

252.65.text:
and held on to
the very end of it

254.12.text:
and let it circulate around
and around in the pool

256.66.text:
in that turbulent,
sort of, cave.

260.96.text:
a bit of it grazed
Matt's knuckles

263.30.text:
and he grabbed--
grabbed the rope,

266.23.text:
he got a breath using his
last little bit of oxygen.

269.50.text:
And, he and I had worked at
a summer camp for years

272.91.text:
together and we had always
taught the kids,

275.34.text:
"Oh, this is how you do this
cool trick knot,

279.35.text:
and if you ever fall off
a cliff,

281.08.text:
- with one hand on the rope...
- ( audience laughter )

285.05.text:
And so that was how we got
kids to get excited about it.

287.52.text:
And we never-- We always
thought that was total BS.

289.99.text:
- ( audience laughter )
- Until he pulled himself up,

292.69.text:
threw one handed bow
and then fell back into the rope

295.63.text:
and Brian was able
to pull him up just enough

297.83.text:
and Matt clawed his way back up
onto the cliff, right?

300.70.text:
And I was watching this with
my flash light at this point,

303.50.text:
my head lamp,
because it was dark.

305.24.text:
So, Matt passed out
from total exhaustion

311.91.text:
separated from his boat,
separated from his gear,

314.21.text:
with nothing on
but his kayaking gear

317.12.text:
to shiver and snuggle with Brian
all night long.

321.05.text:
And... So the next morning,
the rest of our job

323.86.text:
was, kind of,
to get up and around...

328.06.text:
...to a place that we could
rappel down

331.30.text:
Make sure that
he could swim safely,

333.27.text:
run safety for him,
as he swam

335.43.text:
across the river upstream
of the rapid

337.20.text:
that had nearly killed him
the night before.

340.01.text:
And so, that's where
I got to the end of my rope.

343.51.text:
And I was sitting there
thinking to myself:

351.88.text:
And few of the reasons
that really...

357.62.text:
I think
are really important lessons

359.73.text:
that I bring with me
on and off the river.

362.66.text:
And I want to share a few,
a few of them with you.

367.53.text:
whether or not to
run a rapid, right?

369.40.text:
That's one of the
most important decisions

370.74.text: you can make as a kayaker:

372.34.text:
when to run and
when to walk around it.

374.21.text: And so, what I first want to do

376.44.text:
is I want to look at
all of the hazards, right?

378.51.text:
I want to look at all the things
that are terrifying

380.31.text:
and dangerous about that,
that particular rapid.

384.12.text:
or any risk you want
to take, right?

385.38.text:
I want to look at the
dangerous things.

387.19.text:
Look at the--
I want to know where they are,

388.85.text:
what they are and
what they might do to me,

390.92.text:
if I mess up
and how to get around them.

393.19.text:
And I, kind of, like to hold
those things in my fear hand.

396.63.text: And then I like to think about

398.93.text:
why I want to paddle this rapid,
right?

401.40.text: There's good reasons to do it.

402.97.text:
I love being immersed in this
beautiful river

406.47.text:
and working with it
to get myself safely

411.81.text:
But there's also other reasons,
right?

413.68.text:
Maybe we want to
impress our friends.

415.48.text:
Maybe there's a really good
photographer on the trip

417.02.text:
and you want to get
that awesome image.

418.35.text:
Maybe you've got some
camera courage going.

422.09.text:
I like to think of those things
as, kind of, the ego

425.19.text:
and I like to hold those things
separate, right?

428.16.text:
So that I can, kind of,
acknowledge them

430.30.text:
because they are there,
they are real,

431.36.text: they exist for all of us.

433.00.text:
But I don't want them to be part
of my decision making process.

435.13.text:
And so, once I've separated
those two out,

439.17.text:
I've got to, kind of, listen to
my gut and my intuition, right?

442.11.text:
And say,
"Can you run this rapid safely?"

449.92.text:
beautiful moment, right,
when you really decide,

454.32.text:
when you are able to separate
out these things.

460.56.text:
running hard white water
is 60 percent mental,

464.00.text:
and 40 percent actually
being strong and paddling

466.27.text:
and having it balanced
and knowing the strokes.

468.43.text:
Because this is
a hard process to fake,

470.50.text:
to really be honest
with yourself.

472.40.text:
About why you want to do this,
and can you do it, right?

476.14.text:
And so,
once you've reached that point

479.31.text:
and you've really separated out
the fear and the ego

483.38.text:
and you've checked in
with your gut,

485.75.text:
there's this beautiful moment
of clarity

489.02.text:
and, kind of,
freedom that I feel.

491.29.text:
And it's kind of, it's this
euphoric and rare thing.

494.69.text:
And as you take
that last stroke,

496.76.text: you paddle out of the eddy,

498.90.text:
that stroke that commits you
into paddling a drop,

503.00.text:
into a decision that you've made
wholly on your own

506.74.text:
to run this,
to take this risk

510.98.text:
That's one of the
most empowering feelings

513.05.text:
I've ever had
in any experience in my life.

516.15.text:
Because that is where we really
unlock our true passion.

520.72.text:
We unlock and, we sort of,
are able to get in touch with,

524.66.text:
you know,
what makes us tick,

526.76.text:
in our really--
our true potential.

529.09.text:
We are able to do, you know,
what we are here to do.

532.23.text:
And so, what I needed to do
at that moment

536.80.text:
and get to the bottom
of the Pandi River Canyon,

540.81.text:
Matt was able to swim across,
no problem.

544.54.text: He got up, he got out.

546.35.text: We got him to his boat

547.65.text:
and we paddled for the
rest of the week downstream

553.05.text:
to sea descent of the
Pandi River Canyon.

555.49.text:
And, as I think about
that expedition,

558.69.text:
and as I, sort of,
reflect on that,

560.83.text: I think it's clear to me now,

563.00.text:
seven, eight years later
and many expeditions later,

566.93.text:
that, you know,
I let that ego get in my way.

570.20.text:
I really wanted the photos
that Matt would take

573.74.text:
because he is a
great photographer.

575.24.text:
And so I invited him
on an expedition

581.38.text:
You know,
I got him into a situation,

583.65.text: we all got into a situation,

585.35.text:
that he couldn't get out of
on his own.

587.32.text:
And almost paid
a really big price for that.

589.59.text:
And that's something I,
kind of, carry with me

591.02.text:
in my decision-making processes
in life

595.39.text:
I think if I'm going to
risk my life

599.63.text:
I want to make sure that that
story is really worth telling.

604.77.text:
that really helps us
as individuals,

610.08.text:
decide how we want to relate
with each other

614.98.text:
that make life on this
Earth possible.

616.65.text: So, I hope that everybody will

618.48.text:
challenge yourselves
to be risk takers

620.89.text: and make it to the end.
